Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AF: Small: Combinatorial Complexity Problems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Computational complexity characterizes what kinds of computational resources,<br/>such as time, effort, space and energy, <br/>are needed to solve challenging mathematical problems derived from real-world<br/>activities, such as designing<br/>aircraft, analyzing DNA evidence, or breaking a secret code.<br/>This project applies recent cutting-edge work from combinatorics and<br/>algebra to more clearly determine which problems are intractable (before<br/>too many computational resources are wasted trying to solve them). This is important because,<br/>knowing that a problem is hard to solve computationally can be<br/>used in a different direction, such as creating codes that are harder to<br/>break. Combinatorics is the ancient art of counting complicated mathematical<br/>objects, and was the cradle for the development of early digital computers.<br/>Algebra here refers to the study of certain symmetries which have recently<br/>been discovered to be important in complexity theory. <br/><br/>More technically, this project approaches Geometric Complexity Theory<br/>from the point of view of algebraic combinatorics to further clarify<br/>feasible approaches to the VP vs. VNP Problem.<br/>Specifically, part of the work will be devoted to the computational complexity<br/>of counting certain Young tableaux and computing related constants<br/>and polynomials in Algebraic Combinatorics and Algebraic Complexity,<br/>respectively. These objects and quantities, while introduced in the beginning<br/>of last century, are still not deeply understood. However, they have recently<br/>enjoyed a healthy stream of advances from<br/>various directions. Understanding their computational nature would clarify the<br/>feasibility of some famous problems in Algebraic Combinatorics searching for<br/>natural correspondences (bijections), and pave a new approach to their study,<br/>leading towards better lower bounds in algebraic complexity. These objects and<br/>quantities include understanding the Kronecker coefficients (an 80-year-old<br/>problem), and efficiently computing Kostka and Littlewood-Richardson<br/>coefficients. While no closed-form formulas for these coefficients exist,<br/>their asymptotics can lead to new lower bounds in Geometric Complexity Theory<br/>that are currently out of reach.<br/>Specifically, distinguishing Arithmetic<br/>Complexity classes like VP and VNP boils down to distinguishing their<br/>universal polynomials (e.g. determinant vs permanent) under affine<br/>transformations, ultimately translating to inequalities between representation<br/>theoretic multiplicities involving the quantities mentioned.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
